misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Solved a different problem (distance between points) instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The submitted program computes the Euclidean distance between two 2D points instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the keyboard and, using conditional statements, print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinate pairs ('Enter x1 and y1', 'Enter x2 and y2') instead of a single grade.
Program performs arithmetic DX = X2 - X1, DY = Y2 - Y1 and uses Math.sqrt instead of any conditional checks on a grade value.
Program outputs 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: ...'.
No if/else or switch logic to distinguish A/B/C/D/F ranges appears anywhere in the code.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment instructions or reuse of a solution to a different textbook/example problem rather than implementing the required grade-to-letter mapping.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design the program around a single numeric grade input. Replace the distance computation with an if-else chain that checks the grade against the 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, and below-60 ranges and prints the correct letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (inputs, calculations, and output message) corresponds to a distance-formula exercise and there is no code related to reading a grade or mapping ranges to letters.

evidence.note: Entire main method is dedicated to reading two points and computing distance; there is no reading of a single grade, no conditional ranges for grades, and the output refers to distance rather than a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Complete Task Misalignment (Wrong Program Submitted)
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete program designed to calculate the distance between two points, which is a different problem entirely. The code does not contain any logic for reading a numeric grade, implementing conditional ranges, or outputting a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either believes the submitted Distance Calculator program fulfills the requirements of the Grade Calculator task, or they accidentally submitted a solution for a different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must focus on the grading requirement: reading a single grade and using `if`/`else if` logic to assign a letter based on the specified numeric ranges.
symptoms: Prompts ask for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Reads four floating-point inputs instead of one integer grade
Calculates distance using the Pythagorean theorem
Outputs a numerical distance instead of a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to follow the assignment instructions or submission of a previously written, unrelated solution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement for Q3: Grade Calculator. Delete the distance calculation code and write new code that focuses on reading a single grade and using `if-else if-else` statements according to the grading scale (A, B, C, D, F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code implements the Euclidean distance formula exactly and features input prompts and variable names clearly related to coordinate geometry, proving it is the wrong program for the Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: The class name itself indicates the code's purpose is not grading.
The input prompts and variables are for coordinates, not a numeric grade.
The core logic calculates distance, not grade ranges.

misconceptions.name: Reads coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for and reads two (x, y) coordinate pairs instead of a single numeric grade between 0 and 100. As a result, there is no variable representing the requested grade value.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly one numeric grade value (0–100) from the keyboard, using a prompt like "Enter grade:" and store it for later conditional checks.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade
Multiple numeric inputs are read instead of a single grade input
There is no variable that clearly represents a grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. Replace the coordinate prompts and inputs with a single prompt for a numeric grade, e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();`.
related_concepts: Reading a single value from the keyboard using Scanner
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, prompts, and variables all refer to points and distance, with no mention of grades, strongly indicating the student solved a different problem.

evidence.note: Program reads two coordinate pairs instead of a single numeric grade input.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No conditional checks for A or B grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any Boolean conditions to test whether the numeric grade is in the A (90–100) or B (80–89) ranges. In fact, there are no conditionals at all related to grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to compute the distance formula; I do not need to check value ranges or use if-statements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use conditional logic (e.g., if/else-if) to test whether the grade is between 90–100 for A and 80–89 for B, and then output the corresponding letter.
symptoms: No `if`, `else if`, or `else` statements in the program
No Boolean expressions involving a grade variable
Output never mentions letter grades A or B
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the student implemented a distance-calculation problem, they never attempted the required conditional structure for grade ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a single grade value, add `if` / `else if` conditions to check `grade >= 90` for A and `grade >= 80 && grade < 90` for B, and print the correct letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditionals or grade-related variables anywhere in the code, so the required Boolean ranges cannot be present.

evidence.note: Uses arithmetic for distance; there are no `if` or `else` statements to implement A/B grade ranges.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: No conditional checks for C or D grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program has no logic to detect whether a numeric grade falls into the C (70–79) or D (60–69) ranges. It never branches on a grade value at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: Only the distance calculation is required; intermediate grade ranges (C and D) are not needed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should explicitly handle the C and D ranges, typically with conditions like `grade >= 70 && grade < 80` for C and `grade >= 60 && grade < 70` for D, and output the corresponding letters.
symptoms: No grade variable is defined, so C and D ranges cannot be tested
No conditional statements implement any middle ranges
Output never includes letters C or D
misconceptions.root_cause: Solving the wrong problem (distance formula) led the student to omit any conditional structure for middle grade ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Once you introduce a `grade` variable and an if/else-if chain, include explicit conditions for C and D ranges before falling back to F.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditionals and no grade variable, making it impossible that C/D ranges are implemented.

evidence.note: The entire program lacks any conditional statements that could implement the C and D grade ranges.

misconceptions.name: No default/else case to handle failing grades
misconceptions.description: There is no `else` or default branch to handle grades below 60. In fact, there is no branching based on grade at all, so failing cases are never considered.
misconceptions.student_belief: There is no need for a catch-all or default case because I am not categorizing grades.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After checking A, B, C, and D ranges, the program should use an `else` clause to treat all remaining valid grades as F (below 60). This ensures full coverage of the 0–100 domain.
symptoms: No conditional statements or else clause
No branch that mentions or prints 'F'
Program cannot distinguish any failing case from passing ones because it never inspects a grade
misconceptions.root_cause: By implementing only a numeric distance calculation, the student omitted the entire decision structure including the necessary final else case for F.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After implementing conditions for A, B, C, and D, add an `else` at the end that prints `Letter grade: F` for all remaining grade values.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The absence of any if/else structure and any reference to F or failing grades makes it clear that F handling is missing.

evidence.note: Program goes straight from computing distance to printing it and exiting, with no opportunity to handle an F or any grade category.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs numeric distance instead of letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program prints a numeric distance between two points (e.g., 'The distance of the two points is ...') instead of printing a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the input grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The required output is the distance between two points, expressed as a numeric value.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The required output is a letter grade corresponding to the numeric grade input, with a message like `Letter grade: B`.
symptoms: Output message refers to 'distance of the two points'
No `System.out.println` that prints 'Letter grade:' or any isolated letter
User never sees a letter grade result
misconceptions.root_cause: The student is implementing a distance-formula exercise instead of the grade mapping task, leading to a completely different output format and meaning.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the output to `System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter);` where `letter` is a `char` or `String` set in the if/else-if chain based on the numeric grade.
related_concepts: Mapping computed results to user-friendly output
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only output line clearly prints a distance description with no mention of grades, so the letter-grade mapping is completely absent.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + DISTANCE);
evidence.note: Final output reports a numeric distance instead of a letter grade.

misconceptions.task: N/A (Did not attempt the requested task)
misconceptions.name: Submitting Incorrect Solution for a Different Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete program for calculating the distance between two points, which is entirely unrelated to the requested task of calculating a letter grade based on a numeric score.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either mistook the problem statement, uploaded the wrong file, or believes the submitted code fulfills a requirement (e.g., they might think they needed to demonstrate input/output or math functions generally, or simply submitted the code for Q2/Q1 instead of Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must specifically implement the logic required by the Q3 problem statement (reading a single grade and using conditional statements to map it to a letter grade).
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer input (grade)
Code performs a distance calculation using the Pythagorean theorem instead of grade banding logic (if/else if/else)
The class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints'
misconceptions.root_cause: Mismanagement of files, misunderstanding which problem the code addresses, or extreme oversight in reading the prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the Q3 problem statement and write the code that implements the grade calculation logic using appropriate conditional statements (if/else if/else). Ensure you are submitting the correct file for the corresponding question.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is a complete, working solution for a different, identifiable problem (distance between two points) and contains none of the elements required for the Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: The student submitted a solution for calculating the distance between two points, not the grade calculator required by Q3. The entire file is incorrect for the assigned task.
